subject: RE: [junit] Limiting test cases with JUnit task in Ant

messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Shawn Bertrand

> Whether the "fileset" task includes a class specifically or
> via wildcard, JUnit will instantiate a TestSuite,
> reflectively find all methods in a class that begin with
> "test", and then attempt to execute them. In our cases,
> there are a number of existing methods which begin with
> "test" but are protected and thus do not get executed.
> However, this leads to test method failures. Now, I could
> rename these methods to avoid the errors, but I am hoping to
> find a way around it so that developers in the future could
> add methods to future test classes without having to worry
> about not naming them test*.

This is a pretty good illustration of why annotations are a better way to
flag test methods than method names.

When you call your method testFoo(), you are actually using a Java trick to
add metadata to this method, but by doing that, you are hijacking the Java
type system for something it wasn't designed for.

Of course, this trick doesn't scale very well either. Imagine you are using
another tool that automatically generates RMI proxies for all your methods
that start with "remote", and you can see where this leads.

I believe the following is cleaner (and more modern):

@Test
@Remote
@Stateless
public void launchServer() {
// test that the server was launched correctly
}
